instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.Q7180: What is Q7180? Inrush limiter transistor that must be told by the ISL6259 that it is safe to allow charger voltage to pass through to the computer. This needs CHGR_AGATE and CHGR_SGATE to be pulled down in order for it to close and allow voltage through to the system, current sensing failures as well as ISL6259 failures can cause this to happen. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
Hey all i got a mbp which has strange issue. it chimes but doesn't turn on.
no history - no sign of droppage or liquid.

When i hold power button i get chime. fan doesnt spin and cpu gets very hot.

When i disconnect battery and press power button i get no chime and no sign of power.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.68v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.46v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 3.3v

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3_CPUDDR</SIGNAL> 1.19v
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> 1.20v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> 1.8v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> 1.5v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> 1.05v
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> 1.89v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
If chimes, board turns on.
But you have another problem if nothing appears on the screen.

Fan doesn't spin from the beginning as normal behaviour on this model.

Use original Magsafe 2 60/85W charger.
Magsafe 1 --> 2 adapter is known to generate backlight issue.

Seems like your board only starts with battery.
Did you try to start in SMC bypass mode, on charger only?

Post <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> voltage, pins 2, 3, 9, 15, 12, 13, 14, 26 (only charger connected).
Do you get 3V42 on charger mode (no battery)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message: Your device is turning on with no image. Do you get a light on a USB mouse or any external video? The CPU getting super hot doesn't give much hope for this one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
Hey informaticos pins for <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
2- 16.77v
3- 3.99v
9- 0.02v
12- 3.45v
13- 3.13v
14- 3.13v
15- 0.04v
26- 14.37v

also pp3v42g3h present when only power connected (no battery)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message: also john yes activity present on usb :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> signal.
Measure (onboard, ohm scale) <RESISTOR>R7180</RESISTOR>/81 and <RESISTOR>R7185</RESISTOR>/86.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
3.4v on <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>
<RESISTOR>R7180</RESISTOR> <RESISTOR>R7181</RESISTOR> <RESISTOR>R7185</RESISTOR> <RESISTOR>R7186</RESISTOR> all good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
"all good"
Can you post exact value for all?
Remember to measure them onboard...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7180</RESISTOR> 100k
<RESISTOR>R7181</RESISTOR> 62.5k
<RESISTOR>R7185</RESISTOR> 471k
<RESISTOR>R7186</RESISTOR> 316.1k

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
OK, then <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> looks good.
Now post (only charger connected) <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> (<RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16) and check for any reaction at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals...

Don't forget,
"Use original Magsafe 2 60/85W charger."

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
hey informaticos thank you for your reply.
I am using original magsafe 2 60w charger.

I have
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> 3.35v
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> 3.25v
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v

Im not sure how to do this informaticos. "Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> (<RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16) and check for any reaction at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals..." any additional help will be much appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
"Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> (<RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16) and check for any reaction at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals..."
Short <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads, less than 1s, like pressing power button.
Better even, solder tiny wire on <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and touch the ground...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message: When u say check signals on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals - u mean on mutilmeter?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
If multimeter doesn't catch any pulse at least, then should be good to try witb an o-scope; it will catch any pulse.
Usually, multimeter is good enough; it should catch something, if you trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> repeatedly...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
ok so its at 3.4v and when i short <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR> drops to .3v on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>


<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> pulse should i test all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX</SIGNAL> lines?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
Check them all.
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> enables S3 state and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> enables S0 state.
If pulse, check if controlled voltages pulse too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message: Ok please be patient with me. I am new to oscilloscope. So basically when i test the <SIGNAL>PM_SLP</SIGNAL> lines i get two types of reading - one is just an instant voltage change - this is when voltage just goes from 3.3v to 0 when i press power OR second type of reading i get is the voltage goes up and down in a very short 100-200ms <- is this what you mean by pulse?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> should drop to 0V and goes back to 3V instantly; after <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is released.
All <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> lines should go high and stay there.
At the same time, <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> must go high too.
For some reason all drop to 0V because of a power issue, I suppose.
You must check if all these try to go high at least.

If <SIGNAL>AL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> doesn't even pulse, SMC/PCH will stop the power sequence.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
the only time they drop to zero is when i hot <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> otherwise all are high including <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> doesnt pulse always high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
If <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> stays high, you must have all the voltages present; maybe excepting CPU ones.
Please confirm which is your situation.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
cpu is 1.9v

all voltages present even s0 but without pressing power on? dont these models need to be power on for s0?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
All the iCore MacBooks start directly when charger is connected; if no battery present.

Check for USB activity.
Also try PRAM reset.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
Hey informaticos. please excuse me, i re-read your post again. I solder the wire <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and i touch to ground for 1 sec. i was holding for longer before with tweezers.

so i get pulse on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>

but [B]NO pulse[/B] on:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_BTMUX_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_R_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL>

i also try pram and there is USB activity

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message: USB activity is bueno. With a known good test screen, do you get any thing on the screen? How about externally?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
I don't understand what you do there.
Impossible to have S3/0 voltages if you don't even get a pulse on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals.
Do you get all them steady high level?
I asked for pulse supposing all stay low...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
John there is no external could it have any problem with <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>?

informaticos <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals are all steady high. when i press power <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> it doesnt pulse doesnt go low it just stay high. im sorry if i didnt understand you correctly.

thanks for your replies.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
Ok, so MLB is powered up, even CPU.

Can you confirm USB activity with OSX pendrive with Link LED?
If flashes, there is USB activity for sure.
Disconnect internal SSD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message: Yes usb activity present. I have osx on external hdd via usb light flashes and drive spins up. Disconnected ssd. I will try another display but strange no external?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
Do you get 5V at pins 28-30 of J8300, at least in the first few seconds?
It should, even without LCD.
If LCD is connected, <SIGNAL>LCD_HPD_CONN</SIGNAL> should rise to 2.5V and <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> to 3.3V.
If not, 5V will drop too from J8300.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message: Yes there is 5v at pins 28-30 on lcd connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
If you get steady 5V there, means LCD is recognized.
You should get image at least; check with torch from backside.
Do you get any voltage at pin 1/J8300?

I recommend to test with known good LCD assembly (compatible).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message: Yes use a known good 2015 Retina LCD for testing purposes it sounds like you should at least have image. Check pin 1 of J8300 as 2informaticos said.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message: nothing on pin 1.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7700</CHIP> no voltage on pin 1+2
but 5v present on 5 18

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message:
Do you get voltage at pins 11 & 17 of <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>?
Check F7700 and <RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR>/32.

Can you confirm image?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message: Hey guys. Good news, got it working hard short on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_BLT</SIGNAL> injected voltage and found <CAPACITOR>C7760</CAPACITOR> was short. changed that still didnt have voltage coming through <DIODE>D7710</DIODE> changed that too problem solved now working thanks guys

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a doesnt turn on - chimes
threads.message: Good job! Nicely done
